docs.snippet: SCANDAL    Or Priscilla's Kindness.  By A. N. Wilson.  233 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95.     SOMEWHERE between the worlds of Evelyn Waugh and Harold Pinter lies a whole prickly realm of English social life. Angry, punctilious, alarmed and lonely p...
docs.lead_paragraph: SCANDAL Or Priscilla's Kindness. By A. N. Wilson. 233 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95. SOMEWHERE between the worlds of Evelyn Waugh and Harold Pinter lies a whole prickly realm of English social life. Angry, punctilious, alarmed and lonely people fight each other off with what they take to be good manners, and occasionally unearth aspects of themselves that are so shocking they can only bury them again immediately or cultivate them in the quietest corridors of secrecy. The English are often said to be especially tolerant of eccentrics, and they are. But this is in part because their normality itself is so strange, so full of jumps and twitches.

byline.original: By Michael Wood; Michael Wood, author of ''Stendhal'' and ''America in the Movies,'' is a professor of English at the University of Exeter

docs.snippet: One of the highest compliments that can be paid to a performer who's been around awhile is that he or she is still capable of eliciting surprise. Ann-Margret, the initially brassy, belting, singing-dancing actress who made her film debut in 1961 a...
docs.lead_paragraph: One of the highest compliments that can be paid to a performer who's been around awhile is that he or she is still capable of eliciting surprise. Ann-Margret, the initially brassy, belting, singing-dancing actress who made her film debut in 1961 at the age of 20, has been more or less surprising us with regularity since 1971, when she won her first Oscar nomination for her work in the bitterly funny Mike Nichols-Jules Feiffer comedy, ''Carnal Knowledge.'' After ''Carnal Knowledge,'' surprise has become so built into her career that we almost take it for granted. There were her extraordinary physical recovery and return to nightclubs just three months after a near-fatal fall backstage at Las Vegas in 1972, and then her second Oscar nomination for ''Tommy'' in 1975. In the following years there have been wonderfully adroit, comic performances - as Flavia, the dangerously young wife to an ancient Trevor Howard in Marty Feldman's ''Last Remake of Beau Geste,'' and as the lascivious Lady Booby in Tony Richardson's vastly underrated film adaptation of ''Joseph Andrews'' - and equally serious performances, the most spectacular being her work as Blanche Dubois in last year's television adaptation of ''A Streetcar Named Desire.'' What might she do for encores? She seemed to have touched all the possible bases but, as it turns out, not quite.

docs.snippet: Three men linked to investigations of arms and drug smuggling were indicted today on charges they conspired to take $5.8 million in cash out of the country in a jet.   The men were arrested on Feb. 6 at the Kleberg County Airport, where their Sabr...
docs.lead_paragraph: Three men linked to investigations of arms and drug smuggling were indicted today on charges they conspired to take $5.8 million in cash out of the country in a jet. The men were arrested on Feb. 6 at the Kleberg County Airport, where their Sabreliner jet had landed, and the police confiscated six suitcases stuffed with the money. The three men, Gus Maestrales, Francisco Rodrigo Guirola-Beeche and Oscar A. Rodriguez-Feo, conspired to take more than $10,000 out of the United States between Jan. 20 and Feb. 6, according to the indictment returned by a Federal grand jury.

headline.main: 3 INDICTED IN PLOT TO FLY $5.8 MILLION OUT OF U.S.

docs.snippet: Alan Fine went to a cocktail party at Regine's this week in honor of a stuffed something called a Wuzzle. Leonard Wane and Colette Rooney celebrated the Barbie doll's birthday at a black-tie dinner at the Waldorf- Astoria. All three of them watche...
docs.lead_paragraph: Alan Fine went to a cocktail party at Regine's this week in honor of a stuffed something called a Wuzzle. Leonard Wane and Colette Rooney celebrated the Barbie doll's birthday at a black-tie dinner at the Waldorf- Astoria. All three of them watched a $500 robot named Ominibot 2000 make wisecracks and serve diet 7-Up. But they missed the life-size Cabbage Patch Kid dolls who hugged visitors and tried to comb their hair. Mr. Fine, Mr. Wane and Mrs. Rooney, all buyers for Zayre's stores, have bought about 300,000 Barbie dolls and 125,000 Wuzzles so far. They are still fine-tuning their order of Cabbage Patch Kids and have not yet decided whether their customers are quite ready for a talking robot. Such is the nature of business at the Toy Fair, where 12,000 buyers gathered this week to decide which of 150,000 toys to order for Christmas. In fact, such is the nature of business at trade shows in general: a little hoopla, a lot of brass tacks.

headline.main: AT TOY FAIR: ROBOTS, HOOPLA AND HARD SELL

docs.snippet: -word,'' as one studio marketing executive describes it: ''Space.'' In the wake of ''Dune'' and ''2010'' and their disappointing showings, not to mention the long shadow cast by ''E.T.,'' science fiction films will be stressing the human aspects o...
docs.lead_paragraph: -word,'' as one studio marketing executive describes it: ''Space.'' In the wake of ''Dune'' and ''2010'' and their disappointing showings, not to mention the long shadow cast by ''E.T.,'' science fiction films will be stressing the human aspects of their stories rather than the ray guns. At least that will be true for the next two science- fiction efforts, Paramount's ''Explorers'' and Fox's ''Cocoon,'' both scheduled for summer release and both to have special effects by Lucasfilm's Industrial Light and Magic, although the sci-fi wizardry will not be overemphasized. ''Explorers,'' directed by Joe Dante, is about kids who build an S-ship in their backyard and actually undertake S-travel, but it will be promoted mostly as a human story. As for ''Cocoon,'' which is being directed by Ron Howard, the film to remember is Mr. Howard's ''Splash!'' ''It'll have the same very good-natured, warm, human feeling, but on a much bigger canvas,'' said Fox's marketing vice president, Jack Brodsky. ''Cocoon'' is about extraterrestrials who come to Florida to retrieve something left there several millennia earlier.

docs.snippet: Heinz Eric Roemheld, a composer who wrote the hit song ''Ruby'' and won an Oscar for the score of the film ''Yankee Doodle Dandy,'' has died at the age of 83.   Mr. Roemheld, who died Monday of complications from pneumonia at Humana Hospital, brok...
docs.lead_paragraph: Heinz Eric Roemheld, a composer who wrote the hit song ''Ruby'' and won an Oscar for the score of the film ''Yankee Doodle Dandy,'' has died at the age of 83. Mr. Roemheld, who died Monday of complications from pneumonia at Humana Hospital, broke into the movie business as part of a team of composers and arrangers for the 1930 film ''All Quiet on the Western Front.''

headline.main: Heinz Eric Roemheld Dies; Hollywood Film Composer

docs.snippet: O. Pendleton Thomas, retired chairman of the B.F. Goodrich Company, died Friday at Spring Branch Memorial Hospital in Houston. He was 70 years old and lived in Houston....
docs.lead_paragraph: O. Pendleton Thomas, retired chairman of the B.F. Goodrich Company, died Friday at Spring Branch Memorial Hospital in Houston. He was 70 years old and lived in Houston.

docs.snippet: QUESTION: Who scored more points in his pro basketball career, Jerry West or  Oscar Robertson? Which of the two guards fouled out most often?         West and Robertson played in the National Basketball Association during the same 14-season span o...
docs.lead_paragraph: QUESTION: Who scored more points in his pro basketball career, Jerry West or Oscar Robertson? Which of the two guards fouled out most often? West and Robertson played in the National Basketball Association during the same 14-season span of 1960- 74, and in that time, Robertson scored 1,518 more points (26,710 to 25,192), but West had the better average per game (27.0 to 25.7). Robertson played in 108 more games (1,040 to 932), but fouled out of games only once more than West did (18 to 17).

docs.snippet: Loretta Young will end 24 years of retirement to star in a two-hour television movie, ''Dark Mansions,'' according to the producer Aaron Spelling.         The actress, who is 72 years old, began her movie career in 1927 in ''Naughty but Nice'' and...
docs.lead_paragraph: Loretta Young will end 24 years of retirement to star in a two-hour television movie, ''Dark Mansions,'' according to the producer Aaron Spelling. The actress, who is 72 years old, began her movie career in 1927 in ''Naughty but Nice'' and made her last movie, ''It Happens Every Thursday'' in 1953. She won an Oscar for best actress in ''The Farmer's Daughter'' in 1948 and went on to create and star in ''The Loretta Young Show'' on television, which ran from 1953-61.

headline.main: Loretta Young to Star In 2-Hour TV Movie

docs.snippet: ''They still hate you!'' he screams. Then, he's shot and killed.   The meaning of the victim's last words - he was an Army sergeant in the World War II and a most sinister one - turns out to be even more of a mystery than the identity of the murde...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''They still hate you!'' he screams. Then, he's shot and killed. The meaning of the victim's last words - he was an Army sergeant in the World War II and a most sinister one - turns out to be even more of a mystery than the identity of the murderer.
